Firms pump billions into pensions
 
 Employers have spent billions of pounds propping up their final salary pensions over the past year, research suggests.
 
 A survey of 280 schemes by Incomes Data Services' (IDS) said employer contributions had increased from £5.5bn to £8.2bn a year, a rise of 49.7%. Companies facing the biggest deficits had raised their pension contributions by 100% or more, IDS said. Many firms are struggling to keep this type of scheme open, because of rising costs and increased liabilities. A final salary scheme, also known as a defined benefit scheme, promises to pay a pension related to the salary the scheme member is earning when they retire.
 
 The rising cost of maintaining such schemes has led many employers to replace final salary schemes with money purchase, or defined contribution, schemes. These are less risky for employers. Under money purchase schemes, employees pay into a pension fund which is used to buy an annuity - a policy which pays out an income until death - on retirement.
 
 IDS said there were some schemes in good health.
 
 But, in many cases, firms had been forced to top up funds to tackle "yawning deficits". The level of contributions paid by employers has increased gradually since the late 1990s. In 1998/99, for example, contributions rose by 4.7% and in 2002/03 by 8.6%. In contrast, between 1996 and 1998, some employers cut their contribution levels. Helen Sudell, editor of the IDS Pensions Service, said the rise in contributions was "staggering" and the highest ever recorded by IDS. "We have warned before that the widespread closure of final salary schemes to new entrants is just the beginning of a much bigger movement away from paternalistic provision," said Ms Sudell. "With figures like this there can be little doubt that many employers will have to reduce future benefits at some point for those staff still in these schemes."

This has prompted warnings about the closure of many pension plans, potentially leading to reduced future benefits for employees still in these schemes.

In a software company that operates a mix of final salary and money-purchase pension schemes (which is similar to the situation described in the conversation), there are four main departments: HR, Finance, Development, and Operations.
Each department has different responsibilities with respect to managing pensions for its employees.
The HR team's responsibility is managing final salary schemes, while Finance manages money purchase schemes.
The development team takes care of both types of schemes while operations handles only the money-purchase schemes.
There are two key tasks: (1) calculating pension contributions and (2) updating employee records with retirement benefits details.
Each task has a different level of risk associated with it: high, medium, or low.

The following additional information is also known:
- The Finance team always handles the high-risk task.
- Operations, which only manages the money-purchase schemes, never handles the medium-risk tasks.
- In the case of final salary pension plans, it's not possible to switch from one scheme type to another.
- Each department has a different risk tolerance level for each task.
HR prefers low risk, Finance prefers medium and Development is okay with high.
Operations only deals with low-risk tasks.
Question: Which department handles which type of pension scheme (final salary or money purchase) and what task does each handle?
As per the first hint, we know that the Finance team always handles the high-risk task.
Thus, in terms of risk, the Finance team handles both types of schemes.

Since Operations only handles low-risk tasks, it means they are dealing with money purchase pensions since no other department can handle this type of scheme (final salary schemes cannot be switched from one type to another) and the Finance team is already handling high-risk money purchase schemes.
This leaves HR and Development to deal with final salary pensions.
As Operations prefers low-risk tasks, they would not prefer to take on the task of managing final salary pension plans because that would involve medium risk (since this can't be avoided).
This means HR must manage final salary pensions as their preference is for low risk.
This also indicates that Finance and Development have to deal with money purchase schemes since these are all the remaining options for both.

So, the only task left is updating employee records which can be assigned based on the department's risk tolerance levels mentioned in step 3:
- For HR, this could be any of low, medium, or high risk because their preference for tasks with low risk applies to updating employee records as well.
So let's assign a medium level of risk here.
- For Finance and Development, the only option left is managing money purchase schemes which would fall under the medium-risk category as per their preference.

Answer: 
Finance - Final Salary Schemes - High Risk (Calculating pension contributions)
Development - Money Purchase Schemes - Medium Risk (Managing both types of pensions)
HR - Final Salary Schemes - Medium Risk (Updating employee records)
Operations - Money purchase schemes - Low risk (Only low-risk task, managing these schemes)
